item.title: The Quickening
item.description:
â€œâ€œThe hay is in the barn.â€ â€“ (by every coach ever)

Taper week. That strange final chapter in marathon training where the miles drop, but the mind races. Itâ€™s often described as a mix unease, doubt, phantom pains, and the occasional desperate search for â€œbest race-day breakfast.â€

The usual routine, get up, train, recover, repeat, can be replaced if your not careful by second-guessing everything. Did I run enough? Too much? Should I squeeze in one more theshold session? Am I coming down with something? Why does my achilles feel weird?

Most of these concerns come not from logic but from a change in rhythm. After months of structured training, the quiet of taper week feels unsettling, like the calm before a storm.

The Science Behind the Taper

Unlike some many parts of marathon training, the science around tapering is actually pretty solid. It works. Studies show that reducing training volume and intensity in the final weeks leads to better race-day performance. Makes sense, One widely cited meta-analysis suggests that an exponential taper, where training volume is cut more sharply as race day approaches, is especially effective.(Bosquet et al. 2007)

Bosquet, Laurent, Jonathan Montpetit, Denis Arvisais, and IÃ±igo Mujika. 2007. â€œEffects of Tapering on Performance: A Meta-Analysis.â€ Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise 39 (8): 1358â€“65. https://doi.org/10.1249/mss.0b013e31806010e0.

â€œA 2-week taper during which training volume is exponentially reduced by 41â€“60% seems to be the most efficient strategy to maximize performance gains.â€ (Bosquet et al. 2007)

Thatâ€™s reassuring.

For me, peak training landed three weeks out: 36 kilometres of marathon pace work spread over two key sessions. After that, I started to dial things down, both in terms of distance and intensity. Below is my training plan showing how my taper has taken shape leading into race week.

Code 
library(gt)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)

# Load your data
df <- read_excel("data/Taper.xlsx")

# Create gt table
df %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = md("**The Taper ğŸƒâ€â™‚**")
  ) %>%
  cols_label(
    `Week starting` = "ğŸ“… Week of",
    Monday = "Mon",
    Tuesday = "Tue",
    Wednesday = "Wed",
    Thursday = "Thu",
    Friday = "Fri",
    Saturday = "Sat",
    Sunday = "Sun"
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Weekday Training",
    columns = Monday:Friday
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Weekend Sessions",
    columns = Saturday:Sunday
  ) %>%
  opt_row_striping() %>%
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(weight = "bold"),
    locations = cells_column_labels(everything())
  ) %>%
  tab_options(
    table.font.names = "Helvetica",
    data_row.padding = px(6),
    table.width = pct(100),
    heading.title.font.size = 20,
    heading.subtitle.font.size = 14
  )
The Taper ğŸƒâ€â™‚
ğŸ“… Week of
Weekday Training
Weekend Sessions
Mon Tue Wed Thu Fri Sat Sun
23rd June Gym 16k build from 5:40 to 4:10 pace- 1k steady at end 1:20 hours easy to HR Watts thresholds (not too hard) Gym 12k with 8k at MP 18km easy to HR
30th June Gym As above but 12km 1:00 hours easy to HR As per Shiloh Light gym or rest 5km + 6 x 100m at MP RACE DAY

Carb-Loading

Carbohydrate-loading is another classic source of pre-race stress.

Itâ€™s one of those things runners love to debate. Over the years, Iâ€™ve mostly just aimed to bump up my carbohydrate intake in the final few days before a race. Nothing too rigid. Gone are the days of the depletion-then-loading method (where you run yourself into the ground, eat like a bird, then binge on pasta). That modelâ€™s largely been debunked. Instead, the evidence now supports a more balanced approach:

ğŸ‘‰ 10â€“12 grams of carbohydrate per kilogram of body weight per day, ideally during the 36â€“48 hours leading into the race.(Burke et al. 2011)

Burke, Louise M., John A. Hawley, Stephen H. S. Wong, and Asker E. Jeukendrup. 2011. â€œCarbohydrates for Training and Competition.â€ Journal of Sports Sciences 29 (January): S17â€“27. https://doi.org/10.1080/02640414.2011.585473.

At 75 kg, that means around 750â€“900 grams per dayâ€”which, letâ€™s be honest, is a lot of carbs. Luckily Unfortunately, my usual diet is already fairly carb-heavy (hello, white bread and rice), so I wonâ€™t be reinventing the wheel. Iâ€™ll just dial it up a notch, e.g. more sports drinks, soft drinks, etc)

The attached is sample plan thatâ€™s been doing the rounds lately, and Iâ€™ll give this a go broadly speaking during the 48 hours leading into the race.

Download pre race carbo loading

As of writing, weâ€™re officially one week out from the marathon. Iâ€™ve definitely felt the load from the training block, some residual fatigue, a bit of sluggishness on recent runs. Nothing alarming, just the usual signs that the body is ready to recover and sharpen.

With the big stuff now behind me, the aim this week is simple: trust the process, avoid overthinking, stay healthy, and maybe try to sleep a little more (easier said than done).

Regardless of what happens on race day, this training block has been a win. Iâ€™ve found that sweet spot between pushing myself and still enjoying the process. Iâ€™ve managed to avoid overtraining and injury (so farâ€”touch wood).

So hereâ€™s to the final countdown. Let the taper madness begin, but hopefully not take over.

item.title: June Training Plan and intensity progression
item.description:
â€œStart where you are. Use what you have. Do what you can.â€ 1 â€” Arthur Ashe

1 Arthur Ashe Wikipedia.

Iâ€™ve been slack uploading my training plan, but hereâ€™s the plan for from June â€” as of writing iâ€™ve ticked of most of this and its now less than 2 weeks from Gold Coast Marathon 2025.

This was a tough three weeks, and we had to make some adjustments to fit in with work.

Code 
library(gt)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)

# Load your data
df <- read_excel("data/June.xlsx")

# Create gt table
df %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = md("**June Marathon Training Plan ğŸƒâ€â™‚**")
  ) %>%
  cols_label(
    `Week starting` = "ğŸ“… Week of",
    Monday = "Mon",
    Tuesday = "Tue",
    Wednesday = "Wed",
    Thursday = "Thu",
    Friday = "Fri",
    Saturday = "Sat",
    Sunday = "Sun"
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Weekday Training",
    columns = Monday:Friday
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Weekend Sessions",
    columns = Saturday:Sunday
  ) %>%
  opt_row_striping() %>%
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(weight = "bold"),
    locations = cells_column_labels(everything())
  ) %>%
  tab_options(
    table.font.names = "Helvetica",
    data_row.padding = px(6),
    table.width = pct(100),
    heading.title.font.size = 20,
    heading.subtitle.font.size = 14
  ) %>%
    tab_footnote(
    footnote = md("25 to 30 minute very slow jog on most Fridays if no session"),
    locations = cells_column_labels(columns = Friday)
  )
June Marathon Training Plan ğŸƒâ€â™‚
ğŸ“… Week of
Weekday Training
Weekend Sessions
Mon Tue Wed Thu Fri1 Sat Sun
2nd June Gym 18k build from 5:40 to 4:10 pace- 1k steady at end 1:40 hours easy to HR Watts thresholds with 4K WU and WD Gym 16k with 12k at MP 32k with 4 x 4k at MP
9th June Gym As above but 20k 1:45 hours easy to HR Rest 20k with 16km at MP* 34K with 4 x 5K at MP^ Rest
16th June Gym 16k easy to HR with 2k at HMP 1:40 hours easy to HR Watts thresholds with 4K WU and WD Gym 1:40 hours easy to HR Top end of Zone2 (Garmin) 2:30hours
1 25 to 30 minute very slow jog on most Fridays if no session

Training Notes

  • 13 June + 14 June = 36km at marathon pace total. The 16km on the 13th* was fine but the 20k on the 14th^ was a real struggle.

  • 14 June was the peak. Then it was a matter of keeping fit and injury free.

ğŸ‘‰ Strava profile here

Following on from a previous post where I explained my training plan had a heavy focus on specificity, ie running a significant portion of weekly kilometres at or near marathon pace. I was curious to dig into the data and see how well Iâ€™d followed that principle.

Below is a summary table of my running since January, categorised by paces - significantly faster than marathon pace (<4:05 min/km) or at or around my goal marathon pace (4:05â€“4:20 min/km). Obviously, my actual race pace is still to be determined.

One small caveat: June isnâ€™t quite over yet, so there may be a few more kilometres to add before monthâ€™s end.

Interesting, early in the year, marathon pace work was virtually absent, just 1.0 km in January and 0.1 km in February, likely reflecting a period of just turing up to the Watts sessions. Typically this involves a Tuesday (speed) and Thursday (threshold) session, and both run quicker than MP. But April marked a turning point, and a big jump towards goal pace, and that volume has held steady since, with 62.0 km logged in June so far.

Code 
# Create Pace Dataset -----------
library(data.table)
library(tidyverse)

df1 <- fread("data/data_comb4.csv")

pace <- df1%>%
  mutate(
    pace_category = cut(
      pace_sec_per_km,
      breaks = c(-Inf, 245, 260, 300, 330, Inf),
      labels = c(
        "<4:05 min/km",
        "4:05â€“4:20 min/km",
        "4:20â€“5:00 min/km",
        "5:00â€“5:30 min/km",
        ">5:30 min/km"
      ),
      right = FALSE
    )
  ) %>%
  group_by(Month,pace_category) %>%
  summarise(
    Total_Distance_km = sum(Distance, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) %>%
  group_by(Month) %>%
  mutate(
    Percentage_Distance = round(100 * Total_Distance_km / sum(Total_Distance_km), 1)
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# Cleaning -------------

pace$Month <- factor(pace$Month, levels = c("January", "February", "March","April", "May", "June"))

# Create Data Table-------------
library(gt)


#Calculate total monthly distance from full pace dataset
monthly_total <- pace %>%
  group_by(Month) %>%
  summarise(Total = sum(Total_Distance_km, na.rm = TRUE))

# Create pace zone summary for selected categories
summary_table <- pace %>%
  filter(pace_category %in% c("<4:05 min/km", "4:05â€“4:20 min/km")) %>%
  select(Month, pace_category, Total_Distance_km) %>%
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = pace_category,
    values_from = Total_Distance_km
  )


summary_table %>%
  left_join(monthly_total, by = "Month") %>%
  arrange(factor(Month, levels = c("January", "February", "March", "April", "May", "June"))) %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = "Monthly Distance Totals (km)",
    subtitle = "Selected Pace Zones"
  ) %>%
  cols_label(
    Month = "Month",
    `4:05â€“4:20 min/km` = "4:05â€“4:20 min/km",
    `<4:05 min/km` = "<4:05 min/km",
    Total = "Total"
  ) %>%
  fmt_number(
    columns = c(`4:05â€“4:20 min/km`, `<4:05 min/km`, Total),
    decimals = 1
  ) %>%
cols_align(
  align = "center",
  columns = c(`4:05â€“4:20 min/km`, `<4:05 min/km`, Total)
)
Monthly Distance Totals (km)
Selected Pace Zones
Month <4:05 min/km 4:05â€“4:20 min/km Total
January 29.3 1.0 208.4
February 41.1 0.1 231.2
March 33.5 5.0 234.8
April 33.5 59.0 340.0
May 45.9 46.0 367.3
June 31.6 70.0 350.6

item.title: Shoes, Soreness, and the Sweet Spot of Specificity
item.description:
â€œI have been bent and broken, but I hope into a better shape.â€
â€” Charles Dickens

Since my last post in May, the training block has kept ticking along, more or less to plan. The hamstring niggle that flared up in mid-May thankfully settled down (touch wood). But itâ€™s done its job as a persistent reminder: donâ€™t skimp on the gym work. These days, Iâ€™m locked into two lower body sessions a week. Nothing flashy, just the essentials to hopefully to keep the tight hamstring at bay. The rest of the body can wait until after the marathon.

The standout recently? A half marathon in Noosa. I clocked 1:23:20, no PB, but stronger than expected. The plan going in was around 1:25 or 1:26, so it was a pleasant surprise to come home feeling strong. Hereâ€™s the Strava link if youâ€™re curious.

I gave the Saucony Endorphin Elite v2s their debut, and they lived up to the hype. Light, responsive, and aggressive. Thereâ€™s always a temptation to overinterpret a good half marathon performance, but Iâ€™m trying to keep it in context. Iâ€™ve done more marathon specific work than ever before this cycle, so while the shorter race results might not be razor sharp, the hope is that the engine is better tuned for the full 42.2.

I also recently listened to an episode of Eat Sleep Run Repeat1, a podcast produced by some Brisbane based runners which really got me thinking more about specificity. It featured an in-depth interview with coach John Starrett (episode link), who has coached hundreds of sub 3 hour and 2:30 marathoners.

1 Eat Sleep Run Repeat - Podcast.

Starrettâ€™s approach is built around a phased structure that guides athletes from base conditioning through to race readiness. He breaks the training block into distinct segments, what he calls the â€œPre-Superbase,â€ â€œSuperbase,â€ and â€œMarathon Bridge,â€ each with a specific physiological focus. Itâ€™s not just about ramping up mileage, itâ€™s about layering fitness in a deliberate and purposeful way.

What really struck me was how much emphasis he places on quality sessions over quantity. Heâ€™s definitely not a fan of junk miles. His plans centre around two hard workouts per week that target the specific demands of the marathon, using marathon pace and threshold sessions. That approach made a lot of sense, especially in the context of my own build. Another aspect that stood out was his lack of reliance on frequent tune-up races. Instead, he uses well designed marathon pace workouts to simulate the physical demands of race day. While my own program remains different in structure, I found plenty in that conversation that resonated. The specificity, the structured progress and the idea that fewer races might not be a disadvantage after all. Which was especially relevant after Noosa. The week following the half was tough, significant muscle soreness meant I didnâ€™t get back to full training for several days. The race was on the Saturday. Together with some easy running I only managed a 6 km tempo effort the following Thursday, and then an easy 32 km long run on the following Sunday. A definite confidence builder but a reminder races take their toll and require time to recover.

Iâ€™ll post a breakdown of the June training block soon. Thereâ€™s definitely been more marathon pace work creeping in, and itâ€™s starting to feel more comfortable. The last few weeks have built into a big weekend, but Iâ€™ll save that story for next time.

item.title: Marathon Pace and the Long Game
item.description:
â€œIf you feel bad at 10 miles, youâ€™re in trouble. If you feel bad at 20 miles, youâ€™re normal. If you donâ€™t feel bad at 26 miles, youâ€™re abnormalâ€ 1 â€” Robert de Castella

1 Robert de Castella Wikipedia.

Since Iâ€™ve been posting recent training plans, one thing stands out is a definite shift toward marathon pace work. My volume has crept up a little, but the specificity towards marathon paced work has really changed. More long runs with marathon pace segments, more steady-state sessions right around that 4:05â€“4:20/km range. Itâ€™s a deliberate experiment, and Iâ€™m curious where it leads.

Back in 2019, when I ran my marathon PB (2:52), the build-up was strong, but interestingly, I also set PBs in the 5K and 10K. That block had more speed, more threshold, and arguably, more overall fitness. But it had less dedicated work at goal pace. Looking back, I wonder if I left something on the table by not targeting the specific physiological demands of the marathon more closely. Arguably the opposite is true, and pushing harder into those peak zones is a better approach.

This time around, Iâ€™m trying to tilt the balance the other way. Less top-end sharpness maybe, but more resilience at race pace. Whether that pays off or just wears me down remains to be seen. Thatâ€™s the trick with marathon training, youâ€™re gambling six to eight weeks in advance.

Of course, no plan survives contact with the road. Iâ€™ve picked up a tight hamstring, so Iâ€™ll be backing off for a few days and hoping thatâ€™s all it needs. These interruptions are frustrating, but theyâ€™re also reminders to be flexible, not just in the schedule, but in mindset. You donâ€™t lose fitness in three days. You do lose perspective if you panic too early.

The upside is I have some time to post some data from my training block, especially the changes between Januraryâ€“April. For this period I have been running fairly consistently but it wasnâ€™t until April that marathon pace work started creeping into more and more sessions. Itâ€™s been interesting to watch that shift in real-time, and even more interesting to see how the body reacts to it. Marathon Pace work is getting more comfortable thatâ€™s for sure.

The plot below was created by pulling done my run data from Garmin Connect, extracting the average pace for each lap and grouping them. My watch is set to lap every 1km. This plot is inspired by one of the wonderful plots made by Anatasia Anastasiadou

April saw a big jump in the purple marathon-paced zone in the graphic below.

Load libraries

Code 
# load libraries -------

rm(list = ls())

library(data.table)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggtext)
library(extrafont)

Load data

Code 
# load data --------

df <- fread("data/data_comb2.csv")

Dataset for plotting

Code 
# Create Pace Dataset -----------

pace <- df%>%
  mutate(
    pace_category = cut(
      pace_sec_per_km,
      breaks = c(-Inf, 240, 260, 300, 330, Inf),
      labels = c(
        "<4:00 min/km",
        "4:00â€“4:20 min/km",
        "4:20â€“5:00 min/km",
        "5:00â€“5:30 min/km",
        ">5:30 min/km"
      ),
      right = FALSE
    )
  ) %>%
  group_by(Month,pace_category) %>%
  summarise(
    Total_Distance_km = sum(Distance, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) %>%
  group_by(Month) %>%
  mutate(
    Percentage_Distance = round(100 * Total_Distance_km / sum(Total_Distance_km), 1)
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# Cleaning -------------

pace <- pace %>% filter(Month != "May")

pace$Month <- factor(pace$Month, levels = c("January", "February", "March","April"))

Plot

Code 
# colours-----------


grid_colors <- c(
  ">5:30 min/km"       = "#5a8192",  
  "5:00â€“5:30 min/km"   = "#c1cbe3",  
  "4:20â€“5:00 min/km"   = "#a4a0d1",  
  "4:00â€“4:20 min/km"   = "#8570b0",  
  "<4:00 min/km"       = "#67206f"   
)


p <-  ggplot(pace, aes(x = Month, y = Percentage_Distance, fill = pace_category)) +

    geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 0.5) +
   scale_fill_manual(values = grid_colors) +

    labs(
        title = "Monthly % Distribution of Kilometres by Pace Zone",
        subtitle = "4:00-4:20 min/km represents target Marathon Pace (MP).",
        caption = " Source: <b> Garmin Connect</b> | Graphic: <b>Chris Edwards</b>",
        y = "Distance Run (km)", 
        fill = "Type"
    ) +
    
    theme_minimal(base_family = "Enriqueta") +
    
    theme(
        
        axis.title.x = element_blank(),
        
        axis.title.y = element_text(size = 9),
        
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 7),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size = 7),
        
        legend.text = element_text(size = 7),         # Smaller text
        legend.title = element_text(size = 8),        # Optional: smaller title
        legend.key.size = unit(0.8, "lines"),         # Smaller boxes
        legend.spacing.y = unit(0.5, "lines"),
        
        legend.position = "right",
        
        panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "grey75", linetype = "dashed", lineend = "round"),
        panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
        
        plot.title = element_markdown(size = 14, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5, margin = margin(t = 2, b = 2)),
        plot.subtitle = element_markdown(size = 10, hjust = 0.5,  color = "grey30", margin = margin(t = 5, b = 10)),
        plot.caption  = element_markdown(margin = margin(t = 25), size = 6, hjust = 1.28),
        
        
        plot.margin = margin(20, 20, 20, 20),
        
        plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#e4e4e3", color = NA) 
    )  +  
        coord_flip()  
        
    
p

item.title: Training Plans
item.description:
For all the GPS data, lactate curves, and laboratory testing, strange as it may seem, thereâ€™s still no gold standard for marathon training. While some interventionsâ€”like carbohydrate loading or taperingâ€”can be studied in isolation, the training plan itself remains elusive: more art than science.

As an interesting review paper states (Knopp et al. 2024)

Knopp, M, D Appelhans, M SchÃ¶nfelder, S Seiler, and Henning Wackerhage. 2024. â€œQuantitative Analysis of 92 12-Week Sub-elite Marathon Training Plans.â€ Sports Medicine - Open 10 (1): 50. https://doi.org/10.1186/s40798-024-00717-5.

â€œ..a major challenge is that the training plan is not just one intervention but a complex mix of many ..â€

and

â€œâ€¦current marathon training plans are mostly experienced based, occasionally supplemented by evidence-based recommendations such as those related to carbohydrate ingestionâ€

In other words, optimal training is some cocktail of long runs, intervals, tempo workouts, recovery days, and taper rituals, handed down from generations past and shaped more by tradition than strict scientific evidence. Unlike a drug intervention, you canâ€™t easily randomise thousands of runners into perfectly controlled training groups for twelve weeks. As a result, much of what guides runners today comes from anecdotal success, coachesâ€™ intuition, and proven practices among running groups.

In the face of this evidence gap, itâ€™s fair to say that marathon training is still governed by the simple principle: what works, works. Yet patterns do emerge, especially when you study successful plans.

One key aspect worth looking at is how runners distribute training intensity across their weekly mileage. When it comes to endurance training, not all kilometres are created equal. Coaches and exercise physiologists often speak in intensity zones. Although there are several models in the literature, I tend to favour the simplicity (and practicality) of sports scientist Stephen Seilerâ€™s three-zone approach.

  • Zone 1 is the intensity up to the first lactate turn point (~2 mmol/L), roughly around 80% of your maximum heart rate.

  • Zone 2 sits between the first and second lactate thresholds (2â€“4 mmol/L), typically around 87% of your HRmax.

  • Zone 3 is above this, where lactate rises rapidly.

Hereâ€™s a nice YouTube video from Stephen Seilers explaining his approach.

The percentage of training time spent in each of these three zones forms the basis for many training strategies. Two of the most widely discussed are pyramidal and polarised training.

Pyramidal training builds a broad base of easy miles (about 70â€“80% in Zone 1), with the remainder spread between Zones 2 and 3. The name comes from the pyramid-like shape: most training at low intensity, less at moderate, and even less at high intensity. Interestingly, this pattern matches the structure of many published marathon training plans (Knopp et al. 2024).

Polarised training, by contrast, pushes the extremes: lots of low-intensity running (Zone 1), some high-intensity efforts (Zone 3), and very little training in the moderate Zone 2. In one intervention study, the polarised model delivered the largest performance gains in well-trained athletes (StÃ¶ggl and Sperlich 2014).

StÃ¶ggl, T, and B Sperlich. 2014. â€œPolarized Training Has Greater Impact on Key Endurance Variables Than Threshold, High Intensity, or High Volume Training.â€ Frontiers in Physiology 5 (February). https://doi.org/10.3389/fphys.2014.00033.

The science on which is optimal is promising but far from settled. A systematic review found that both polarised and pyramidal approaches outperformed threshold-heavy (Zone 2-focused) plans but couldnâ€™t definitively crown a winner (Kenneally, Casado, and Santos-Concejero 2018). More recent research even suggests a periodised blend (another â€œPâ€ word)â€”starting pyramidal and shifting toward polarisedâ€”may offer the best of both worlds (Filipas et al. 2022).

Kenneally, M, A Casado, and Jordan Santos-Concejero. 2018. â€œThe Effect of Periodization and Training Intensity Distribution on Middle- and Long-Distance Running Performance: A Systematic Review.â€ International Journal of Sports Physiology and Performance 13 (9): 1114â€“21. https://doi.org/10.1123/ijspp.2017-0327.
Filipas, L, M Bonato, G Gallo, and R Codella. 2022. â€œEffects of 16 Weeks of Pyramidal and Polarized Training Intensity Distributions in Well-Trained Endurance Runners.â€ Scandinavian Journal of Medicine & Science in Sports 32 (3): 498â€“511. https://doi.org/10.1111/sms.14101.

In short: intensity distribution matters. But how you mix it, like so much in running, depends on timing, experience, and knowing when to hold back and when to push.

Curious about my own training, I took a quick peek at my data.

Taking a spherical cow 1 approach to vastly simplify things (perhaps to my folly!), I scaped my recent running data from Garmin Connect and imported it into R. In the data.frame I have computed three Zones (Z1, Z2, Z3) using the Avg.HR for each lap. My watch is currently set to lap every 1km. For each zone I inferred guesstimated my HR ranges based on my current probable HRmax of around 180bpm.

1 The â€œspherical cowâ€ is a funny way of describing how scientists sometimes oversimplify complex problems into neat, potentially unrealistic models. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_cow

Roughly for April my distribution is fairly pyramidal ( 77% Z1, 16% Z2, 7% Z3).

Output below, and I am keen to track these distributions leading into the race.

Code 
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

# Calculate percentage of time and distance in each Zone

zone_summary <- data %>%
  group_by(Zones, Month) %>%
  summarise(
    Total_Time = sum(Time_seconds, na.rm = TRUE),          # Total time in each zone
    Total_Distance = sum(Distance, na.rm = TRUE)          # Total distance in each zone
  ) %>% group_by(Month) %>%
  mutate(
    Percentage_Time = 100 * Total_Time / sum(Total_Time),  # Percentage of total time
    Percentage_Distance = 100 * Total_Distance / sum(Total_Distance) # Percentage of total distance
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# Display April Table

zone_summary %>% filter(Month == "April") %>% gt()
Zones Month Total_Time Total_Distance Percentage_Time Percentage_Distance
Z1 April 68671.5 203.29 77.041781 71.302304
Z2 April 14425.0 56.34 16.183245 19.760794
Z3 April 6038.9 25.48 6.774974 8.936902
Code 
zone_summary <- zone_summary %>%
  mutate(
    Zones = factor(Zones, levels = c("Z3", "Z2", "Z1")),  # Controls stacking
  )

# Just April

zone_summary_april <- zone_summary %>% 
  filter(Month == "April")

zone_colours <- c(
  "Z1" = "#ffbf00",
  "Z2" = "#f27c23",
  "Z3" = "#e24a6f"
)

ggplot(zone_summary_april, aes(x = Month, y = Percentage_Time, fill = Zones)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.7) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = zone_colours,
    breaks = c("Z1", "Z2", "Z3")  # Reorder the legend
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Training Time Distribution by Zone (April)",
    x = "Month",
    y = "Percentage of Total Time (%)",
    fill = "Zone"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = scales::percent_format(scale = 1),
    expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.05))
  ) +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "top",
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(color = "black")
  )

item.title: April Training Plan
item.description:
Hereâ€™s my training plan for April â€” 12 weeks out from Gold Coast Marathon 2025. Iâ€™ll post the May and June plans a bit later depending on how Iâ€™m travelling â€” time and fitness-wise.

The current focus is on keeping things manageable, with the exception of Thursdays â€” which should feel pretty tough. Saturdays and Sundays start to introduce some marathon pace (MP) efforts, but nothing overwhelming just yet.

Training Notes

  • Thursdays are hard. Thatâ€™s deliberate. The rest of the week should feel sustainable.
  • Missing a running session occasionally is fine. Missing gym work is not.
  • The next 5-week block will build from this. Expect longer MP blocks on Saturdays and extended MP efforts on Sundays.

Want to follow along ğŸ‘‰ Strava profile here

Code 
library(gt)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)

# Load your data
df <- read_excel("data/April.xlsx")

# Create gt table
df %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = md("**April Marathon Training Plan ğŸƒâ€â™‚**")
  ) %>%
  cols_label(
    `Week starting` = "ğŸ“… Week of",

    Tuesday = "Tue",

    tab_footnote(
    footnote = md("Weekend runs easy pace between MP efforts. Heart rate returns to (Garmin) zone 2 before next effort (might mean slowing a lot)"),

  )

item.title: Race Predictors..
item.description:
â€œAll models are wrong, but some are useful.â€1 â€” George Box

1 quote generally attributed to George E. P. Box, a British statistician, who argued models are never perfect by may still be useful in everyday life

Before diving into the training data, letâ€™s take a quick detour into the curious, and sometimes overly optimistic, world of race prediction models. Most runners have come across these at some point: you plug in a recent race result, hit â€œcalculate,â€ and voilÃ  â€” a predicted marathon time appears!

The Riegel equation2, or some variation of it, is perhaps the most well-known. It uses a race result over a known distance to estimate a predicted finish time for another distance, based on an exponential decay formula.

2 proposed by Peter Riegel in a Runnerâ€™s World article in 1977

Specifically, the formula is:

Where:

Tâ‚ = time over distance Dâ‚

Tâ‚‚ = predicted time over distance Dâ‚‚

b = decay exponent - originally proposed by Riegel to be 1.06

Some more sober-minded folks argue the exponent should be higherâ€”closer to 1.15â€”and you can read more about the logic behind that in the linked article - see: FetchEveryoneâ€™s improved Riegel calculator . Running watches also provide predictors. Mine, a Garmin, currently pegs my marathon fitness at 3:11:xx. Where it gets this number from is anyoneâ€™s guess. Presumably a mix of VOâ‚‚ max estimates, and recent efforts.

But there are other prediction methods that draw on your training data rather than race results. After sharing my past marathon times in a previous post, I started wondering how well the training leading into those races actually correlated with my finish times.

Enter Tanda.

Developed by Giovanni Tanda from the University of Genova, this model is based on actual training data, not race times. His 2011 paper(Tanda 2011) looked at a bunch of training logs and used regression analysis to see what best predicted marathon pace (and by extension marathon finish time).

Tanda, Giovanni. 2011. â€œPrediction of Marathon Performance Time on the Basis of Training Indices.â€ Journal of Human Sport and Exercise 6 (3): 511â€“20. https://doi.org/10.4100/jhse.2011.63.05.

The result? For the 8 weeks leading into the final week of training, the paper excluded the final taper week, the two key variables that correlated best with finish times were:

â€¢ K = average weekly distance (km/week)

â€¢ P = average training pace (sec/km)

There are, of course, some obvious limitations to the study. It included a modest number of runners (and only one female), and it didnâ€™t attempt to correlate performance with things like individual VOâ‚‚ max, lactate threshold, body composition, or biomechanicsâ€”factors that are known to influence performance.

Christof Schwiening has written a brilliant blog exploring the Tanda model in depth, for those keen to venture further down the rabbit hole. One of his best analogies compares Tanda nicely to other race predictors:

â€œâ€¦the Tanda 8-week period is just another race. It is the training race â€“ a race with no defined distance or time, but a race nevertheless.â€3

3 Understanding race predictors - Riegel versus Tanda - Christof Schwiening blog

For me, it was just an interesting exercise to see how the model held up. So I went full archaeologist on the 8 weeks leading into all 12 previous marathons. I dug up the P and the K, and ran the Tanda model for each.

Below is the output

Code 
tanda_data %>%
  select(Race, Avg_Dist_week_K,
         Predicted_Time, Pace, Time, Difference, Over_Under_Tanda) %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = "Marathon Performance vs Tanda Prediction"
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Training Summary",
    columns = c(Avg_Dist_week_K, Pace)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Race Performance",
    columns = c(Predicted_Time, Time, Difference, Over_Under_Tanda)
  ) %>%
  cols_label(
    Race = "Event",
    Avg_Dist_week_K = "Avg Weekly Distance (K, km)",
    Pace = "Training Pace (P, sec/km)",
    Predicted_Time = "Tanda Prediction (hh:mm:ss)",
    Time = "Actual Time (hh:mm:ss)",
    Difference = "Difference (mm:ss)",
    Over_Under_Tanda = "Over/Under"
  ) %>%
  fmt_number(
    columns = Avg_Dist_week_K,
    decimals = 1
  ) %>%
  fmt_number(
    columns = Pace,
    decimals = 0
  ) %>%
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md(
      "Tanda equation: $Pm (sec/km) = 17.1 + 140.0 \\cdot \\exp(-0.0053 \\cdot K) + 0.55 \\cdot P$"
    )
  )
Marathon Performance vs Tanda Prediction
Event
Training Summary
Race Performance
Avg Weekly Distance (K, km) Training Pace (P, sec/km) Tanda Prediction (hh:mm:ss) Actual Time (hh:mm:ss) Difference (mm:ss) Over/Under
Gold Coast 81.6 298 03:11:01 03:07:47 03:14 Under
Melbourne 76.3 297 03:12:31 03:38:06 25:35 Over
Boston 75.9 294 03:11:31 03:05:00 06:31 Under
Gold Coast 69.9 280 03:08:10 02:58:12 09:58 Under
Caberra 88.3 277 03:00:42 03:01:21 00:39 Over
Gold Coast 56.6 317 03:27:45 03:39:26 11:41 Over
New York City 71.3 290 03:11:36 03:17:11 05:35 Over
Gold Coast 88.4 309 03:13:05 03:33:49 20:44 Over
Gold Coast 102.4 290 03:01:24 02:52:17 09:07 Under
Gold Coast 72.4 315 03:21:01 03:06:49 14:12 Under
Sydney 79.8 319 03:19:52 03:23:10 03:18 Over
Gold Coast 74.9 297 03:13:15 03:06:33 06:42 Under
Tanda equation: (Pm (sec/km) = 17.1 + 140.0 (-0.0053 K) + 0.55 P)

Iâ€™m not entirely sure how to interpret this. Based on the Tanda predictions, I outperformed the model in half of my races and underperformed in the other half. In other words, it was a coin toss.

The Blandâ€“Altman plot4 below doesnâ€™t offer much insight either. Thereâ€™s no meaningful bias between the Tanda prediction and my actual marathon finish times the blue line howers around 0 on the y-axis. Which I suppose is a good thing.

4 Wikipedia reference for the Bland- Altman plot

Whatâ€™s more concerning is the width of the Limits of Agreement (LoA). The red-dotted lines hovers around Â±25 minutes â€” which is wild. That essentially means thereâ€™s 95% â€œconfidenceâ€ that my actual time could be anywhere within 25 minutes of the Tanda prediction for any given race build-up. Not exactly razor-sharp guidance.

Also, I have a feeling the finishes over 3:30 are skewing the results. Two of those were significant blow-ups â€” races where things really unravelled in the later stages. The third was more of a social run, where I paced comfortably alongside a mate.

All up, itâ€™s a reminder that while models like Tanda can offer a rough guide, they donâ€™t always capture the messiness of the marathon. And maybe thatâ€™s the point: running isnâ€™t always about prediction â€” sometimes itâ€™s about embracing the unknown, the artistry of pacing, the conditions on the day, and that delicate mix of patience and bravery that makes each race its own adventure.

Code 
library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)

# Prepare the data using base conversions
tanda_ba <- tanda_data %>%
  mutate(
    Pred_sec = as.numeric(lubridate::period_to_seconds(lubridate::hms(Predicted_Time))),
    Time_sec = as.numeric(lubridate::period_to_seconds(lubridate::hms(Time))),
    Mean_time = (Pred_sec + Time_sec) / 2,
    Diff_time = Time_sec - Pred_sec
  )

# Compute bias and limits of agreement
bias <- mean(tanda_ba$Diff_time, na.rm = TRUE)
sd_diff <- sd(tanda_ba$Diff_time, na.rm = TRUE)
loa_upper <- bias + 1.96 * sd_diff
loa_lower <- bias - 1.96 * sd_diff

# Custom formatter for x-axis (hh:mm)
sec_to_hhmm <- function(x) {
  hours <- floor(x / 3600)
  minutes <- floor((x %% 3600) / 60)
  sprintf("%02d:%02d", hours, minutes)
}

# Create Blandâ€“Altman plot
BA_plot<- ggplot(tanda_ba, aes(x = Mean_time, y = Diff_time)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = bias, linetype = "solid", color = "blue") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = loa_upper, linetype = "dashed", color = "red") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = loa_lower, linetype = "dashed", color = "red") +
  scale_x_continuous(
    labels = sec_to_hhmm,
    name = "Mean of Tanda Prediction and Actual Time (hh:mm)"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "Difference: Actual - Predicted (sec)"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Blandâ€“Altman Plot: Tanda Prediction vs Actual Marathon Time"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

BA_plot

item.title: The Beginning Stages of..
item.description:
â€œHe who makes a beast of himself gets rid of the pain of being a man.â€ 1 â€” Dr. Samuel Johnson, quoted in Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas by Hunter S. Thompson (1971)

1 Originally by Dr. Samuel Johnson, used by Hunter S. Thompson as the epigraph to Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (1971).

This is the beginning of a small experiment â€” part training log, part data science side project, part nostalgic therapy. After a long and sometimes questionable relationship with the marathon, Iâ€™ve decided to document the road to my next one â€” my 13th, though whoâ€™s counting. A â€œlocalâ€ marathon, the Gold Coast Marathon and one Iâ€™m familiar with. Iâ€™m not chasing a personal best (at least, thatâ€™s what I tell myself), but I am chasing something: structure, understanding, maybe even redemption. This blog, and the series to follow, is a place to reflect on old performances, track new training efforts, and occasionally make sense of the numbers â€” or at least dress them up in tidy tables and plots that suggest control over what is an unpredictable pursuit.

The marathon doesnâ€™t just test the man â€” it spawns the beast in him. Not a beast of rage or reckless indulgence, like the one Hunter S. Thompson conjured in the neon haze of Vegas, but something more controlled, more methodicalâ€¦ yet still, undeniably, irrational. To train for a marathon is to willingly embrace a kind of madness: to rise early, log the miles, sweat through long runs, negotiate splits, and obsess over details that no one else will ever see or care about. No different, I suppose, than other, less healthy forms of additionâ€” except that one ends with a finisherâ€™s medal and (hopefully) less liver damage. Still, both blur the lines between discipline and delusion. And both, in their way, are obsessions that allow escape from the polite constraints of ordinary life.

Reflecting on my own running, I havenâ€™t trained â€œproperlyâ€ since 2019 â€” which, not coincidentally, was also my personal best (2:52). A high-water mark that Iâ€™ve stared at lovingly (and distortedly) in the rear-view mirror ever since. In the time that followed, both the structure and my resolve slipped. My belief systems about what should work in training have often charged ahead of the evidence. In hindsight, I probably need to be a better Bayesian 2: update my beliefs when the data tells me to, not just when my ego needs a pick-me-up.

2 For a general introduction to Bayesian inference â€” the process of updating beliefs as new evidence becomes available â€” see the Wikipedia article on Bayesian inference.

So, why write now?

Partly because Iâ€™m keen to trace the path from start to finish. But also because Iâ€™ll â€œtryâ€ and quietly turn this into a small data science project â€” an excuse to tinker with my training logs, Strava uploads, physiological markers, and the occasional psychological pothole. Maybe thereâ€™s something to learn from 12 previous marathons. And really, I just love running â€” the rhythm, the ritual, the ridiculousness of it all. This is a way to make sense of it, or at least enjoy the attempt.

Itâ€™s also a chance to learn more about Quarto3 (the system used to create this website), and to explore how to tell a story with better visuals, tables, and a cleaner presentation style. Consider it a running diary meets technical playground â€” one foot in the marathon world, the other in R markdown.

3 Quarto is an open-source scientific and technical publishing system. For documentation and source code, see the official website at quarto.org and the GitHub repository.

For background, Iâ€™m including some data below to give a snapshot of my past marathon performances, complete with age-graded percentages. Itâ€™s a mix of highs and â€œwhat the hell happened there?â€

Code 
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

df <- data %>%
  dplyr::select(Date, Race, Time, Age, Age_Graded_Percent = Age_Graded) %>% 
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = "Age-Graded Marathon Performances"
  ) %>%
  fmt_number(
    columns = vars(Age_Graded_Percent),
    decimals = 2,
    suffixing = TRUE
  ) %>%
  cols_label(
    Date = "Race Date",
    Race = "Event",
    Time = "Finish Time",
    Age = "Age",
    Age_Graded_Percent = "Age-Graded (%)"
  )

df
Age-Graded Marathon Performances
Race Date Event Finish Time Age Age-Graded (%)
6/07/2014 Gold Coast 3:07:47 37 69.23
12/10/2014 Melbourne 3:38:06 37 59.61
20/04/2015 Boston 3:05:00 37 70.27
5/07/2015 Gold Coast 2:58:12 38 72.95
10/04/2016 Canberra 3:01:21 38 71.68
3/07/2016 Gold Coast 3:39:26 38 59.24
6/11/2016 New York City 3:17:11 39 65.93
1/07/2018 Gold Coast 3:33:49 40 63.14
7/07/2019 Gold Coast 2:52:17 42 78.36
3/07/2022 Gold Coast 3:06:49 44 72.26
17/09/2023 Sydney 3:23:10 46 69.89
7/07/2024 Gold Coast 3:06:33 47 76.12

One main difference this time is Iâ€™ve handed over the keys to someone else. A friend â€” and experienced runner â€” who is guiding my training. So training plan to come. Left to my own devices, I tend to alternate between over-training, under-believing, and ignoring all evidence in favour of whatever romantic training idea is currently floating through my brain. So this time, Iâ€™m trying structure. Consistency. Restraint. (I give that three weeks, tops!).

So here we are: 13 weeks out. The beginning stages ofâ€¦ I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™ll run sub-3 again. But Iâ€™ll document the attempt, the process, and the data that drips out along the way. Iâ€™m choosing to believe if only for a little while, and at least in this moment it seems worth leaning into.

Letâ€™s see what happens.

item.title: AI in Sonography
item.dc:creator: Christopher Edwards
item.description:
The Rise of AI

Lately, itâ€™s been hard to escape discussions about artificial intelligence (AI) and its potential to reshape our lives. Conversations often focus on its influence on work and whether it will meaningfully impact the role of sonographers. How will it affect education and the training of future professionals? Beyond our field, the media is full of warnings about rogue AIs fuelling social unrest by spreading misinformation or aiding criminals in creating elaborate scams. Recently, AI-generated content â€“ images and videos â€“ has flooded the internet. While some of it is amusing, much of it has little value, earning the nickname â€˜slopâ€™ or â€˜AI-generated spamâ€™.

The recent surge in public interest in AI can be traced back to the release of OpenAIâ€™s ChatGPT in November 2022. However, the technology behind it â€“ specifically the transformer, the â€˜Tâ€™ in ChatGPT â€“ has been around since 20171. Over the past year, there has been a rapid rise in user-friendly interfaces, making the technology accessible to a much broader section of the public. Today, numerous tools allow users to generate high quality text and create images and videos with an ever-expanding range of possibilities. In September, Google released an audio add-on to NotebookLM, their personalised AI collaborator, allowing users to create a podcast from text-based inputs. Could this be a handy study tool? Imagine students uploading their ultrasound physics notes and listening to AI-generated podcasters discuss parallel beamforming on their commute, complete with â€˜umsâ€™ and â€˜ahsâ€™. Thereâ€™s even evidence suggesting that, in specific contexts, AI can explain content more effectively than professors2.

1 Vaswani A. Attention is all you need. Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, 2017. https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.1706.03762

2 Chiasson RM, et al. Does the human professor or artificial intelligence (AI) offer better explanations to students? Communication Education, 2024; 1â€“28. https://doi.org/10.1080/03634523.2024.2398105

Applications that use transformers will continue to evolve. A transformer is an AI model trained via machine learning on vast amounts of data. The training employs a technique called â€˜backpropagationâ€™, a type of feedback loop that improves the modelâ€™s accuracy. During backpropagation, the model calculates the error between predicted and actual outputs and then uses this error to adjust parameters to improve model performance over time. This could be text in the case of large language models (LLMs) or images and videos.

Some of the work currently done at QUT, analysing ultrasound images, uses a type of transformer called a Swin Transformer. The Swin Transformer, short for Shifted Window Transformer, is designed to deal with the complexity of image processing. Unlike text, where information flows sequentially, images are spatially located. For example, in medical images, the diagnosis isnâ€™t just in individual pixels but in how these pixels relate to one another across the entire visual field. Ultrasound images are particularly complex and include various acoustic features that relate to one another, such as their echotexture and position in the image. The correct characterisation of an image may even include features that extend across frames.

Once training is complete, the model doesnâ€™t â€˜relearnâ€™ each time it gets a new prompt; instead, it leverages its pre-learned knowledge to respond in real time. It does this quickly because itâ€™s designed to process information in parallel rather than sequentially, making it highly efficient. Some commercial ultrasound systems have already deployed this technology with onboard AI assistants to highlight particular anatomy or the correct scan plane. For example, targeting a nerve before a pain block or identifying fetal structures during obstetric scanning.

Professional Context â€“ AIâ€™s Role in Sonography Practice

Predicting how this technology will ultimately impact the sonographerâ€™s role is challenging. Some tools may work in the background to improve image quality but others will require direct interactions with the sonographer. Suppose one were to view AI from a purely technical or capability standpoint â€“ for example, a system that employs machine learning to predict an output from text, images, audio or video. With the current level of AI technology, it is perhaps reasonable to suggest that, in a short period, an ultrasound system will be equipped with advanced image analysis tools, possibly automatically labelling anatomy and highlighting a range of pathologies. Further, it may be able to analyse sets of images or videos and compute a report. Regarding audio, perhaps our machines may be equipped with an inbuilt audio interface that will interact with the patient directly, reassuring them that everything is in hand and answering any questions they may have in a professional, empathetic tone. The system may even prompt you if the patient mentions some relevant clinical history, conveniently prefilling these details into an electronic worksheet before you have left the room. What about wholly automated systems using advanced robotics?

The world was promised the widespread adoption of driverless cars; Morgan Stanley in 2013 predicted this would occur in 20263. Current predictions have now gone beyond another two decades. This is partly due to the messiness and unpredictability of real life and the difficulty of designing models to cope. In the case of driverless cars, sudden changes in the weather, roadworks, and, of course, other human drivers engage in irrational behaviour on the road. Healthcare is similarly complex, filled with ambiguity, human emotion, and multiple competing elements. AI models must be robust enough to handle these realities. In sonography, this means dealing with everyday realities like extremes of body habitus, low patient acuity, and challenging patient interactions. Sonographers currently address these issues using techniques such as non-standardised plans and advanced communication skills tailored to each patientâ€™s condition and clinical history.

3 Shanker R, et al. Autonomous cars: Self-driving the new auto industry paradigm. Morgan Stanley blue paper, 2013; 1â€“109.

Various systems will be developed and deployed as technology advances. Following how these systems are implemented and adapted to current healthcare challenges will be interesting. What is clear is that AI systems that make predictions or assist with decision-making cannot be viewed simply in a transactional sense; they are not like calculators involving a simple input and output; it is an interaction that consists of a relationship between the user and the patient (both humans) and the machine. As mentioned above, the success of these systems will be dependent on various patient characteristics but also on how AI relates to individual practitioners. This is about knowing if the tool produces the correct response in the correct setting. In this way, the success of the AI will depend on the practitionerâ€™s experience just as much as its ability to interpret the ultrasound machineâ€™s output. In one scenario, an expert sonographer may quickly identify an error in the AI output, whereas a student or newly qualified sonographer may take the output on trust. AI interactions will require a delicate balance between trust and scepticism. Successfully integrating AI into sonography will mean navigating this new reality.

Sonography Education â€“ Balancing AI Tools and Integrity

The impacts of AI in the sonography profession are likely to be gradual. However, their effect on education, including sonography education, has more immediate implications. Generative AI (GenAI), the term used to describe AI that can create new content, is capable of completing many student tasks with high accuracy, making it one of the most disruptive technologies ever seen in education. The latest ChatGPT release, o1-preview, designed explicitly for advanced logic and reasoning, is reported to perform at the PhD level4.

4 OpenAI. Introducing OpenAI o1-preview. https://openai.com/index/introducing-openai-o1-preview/

5 Parliament of Australia. Inquiry into the use of generative artificial intelligence in the Australian education system â€˜Study Buddy or Influencerâ€™. 2024 https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/House/Employment_Education_and_Training/AIineducation/Report

6 Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency. Artificial intelligence request for information â€“ next steps. 2024.https://www.teqsa.gov.au/about-us/news-and-events/latest-news/artificial-intelligence-request-information-next-steps

Multiple authorities are wrestling with the impacts. A parliamentary senate inquiry report, â€˜Study Buddy or Influencerâ€™, was released in August 2024, recommending GenAI in education be made a national priority5. The Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency (TEQSA), the national regulatory body of universities, has requested urgent action, asking all institutions to report on how they manage GenAI, particularly how they address the risk of GenAI to award integrity6.

Universities themselves also understand the reputational risks and potential for significant community backlash, for example, graduates from a particular university who enter the workforce without the competence to perform the job effectively and safely. This is especially critical in fields like sonography and other health degrees, where universities self-certify their students. Once they graduate, there is no post-qualification check to ensure that the skills they reportedly gained meet community expectations.

With these considerations in mind and TEQSA having one eye firmly on risk, an urgent overhaul of assessment practices is underway. Of course, some assessments are designed to assist and promote learning, and AI tools will become welcome additions. Other, high-stakes assessments designed to verify student learning, which directly leads to certifying a degree like sonography, will require rigorous direct supervision â€“ for example, a return of traditional hall-style written exams to verify knowledge acquisition, oral assessment tasks to demonstrate understanding and showcase communication skills, and face-to-face practical evaluations to demonstrate technical skills.

Many online assessment methods developed during COVID-19 are now obsolete. Numerous tips and YouTube videos are circulating on how students can use AI tools during online assessments, even when the assessor is present via Teams or Zoom. Some may have already seen videos of job candidates using AI tools to convert an employerâ€™s questions into text responses displayed on a hidden monitor during interviews.

Risks must be countered with rewards. In the professional world, it is not unreasonable to expect the question of why you used an AI tool to become â€˜why notâ€™, especially when there are workflow and efficiency gains and improvements to overall patient care. Therefore, it is incumbent on educators to encourage the use of tools for relevant tasks. In the sonography context, this might be written communication tasks where students produce artefacts (reports, oral case presentations, ePoster) to showcase and share their knowledge with colleagues.

The use of AI in learning is also an untapped resource. Feedback literacy, an emerging topic in education to improve student learning outcomes, is one area in which AI may assist. The idea focuses not on how supervisors frame feedback for students but on teaching students to respond positively and integrate feedback into their practice. Feedback comes in various forms; sometimes, it is for evaluation; other times, it is an aid to help the student improve; and at different times, it is for praise on a job well done. All of which are important for growth. How students manage their emotional responses to these three is an important skill to develop. More research is needed, but perhaps AI chatbots may be a good source of feedback literacy development â€“ just a thought.

As AI becomes more integrated into sonography and education, the focus must remain on maintaining the integrity of the profession and upholding community trust in practitioners. While these tools offer potential, ensuring that they enhance rather than replace human judgement and accountability is essential to preserving the core values of patient care and professional competence.

item.title: Celebrating the Art and Science of Sonography
item.description:
October is Medical Ultrasound Awareness Month, and the 27th of October is Australasian Sonographers Day. These are fantastic opportunities to bring the public closer to the incredible ultrasound technology and highlight the essential role sonographers play in modern healthcare. Unlike many imaging techniques, the success of ultrasound examinations depends heavily on the sonographerâ€™s skills, intuition, and expertise. This unique relationship between humans and machines presents challenges and remarkable rewards for those in the profession.

The sonography profession faces several significant challenges today. Increasing demand for imaging services, an overstretched workforce, and a lack of professional recognition are just a few of the difficulties. Furthermore, ongoing concerns about workplace health and safety, alongside a chronic lack of training opportunities for the next generation have compounded the pressures on the field. While none of these challenges have easy solutions, focusing solely on the obstacles would overlook the incredible aspects of sonography that continue to make it a deeply rewarding career. So, what makes this profession so special? Here are three reasons.

The Joy of Mastering a Challenge

One of the most fulfilling aspects of sonography is its inherent complexity. Mastering the skill takes years, and excellence can take decades, but that journey is what makes it so satisfying. John F. Kennedy once said of the quest to land on the moon,

â€œâ€¦not because they are easy, but because they are hard; because that goal will serve to organise and measure the best of our energies and skills, because that challenge is one that we are willing to acceptâ€¦â€

This resonates with sonographers, who are challenged to perform complex tasks daily. Each examination demands technical precision, an understanding of human anatomy, and zero-latency decision-making. The sonographer must simultaneously manipulate the ultrasound probe, adjust the ultrasound beam, interpret numerous images in real-time, and engage with the patient to ensure their comfort and cooperation. It is a dance of skill and intuition, with the patient always at the center of the experience.

As one paper described sonography, it is â€œ25% art, 25% knowledge, and 50% public relations.â€(Mulkey 2005) Every exam is different, requiring a mix of creativity, problem-solving, and a deep connection with the patient. It may look easy to outsiders, but those in the field know the truthâ€”this is a job for those who thrive on challenges.

Mulkey, Allen. 2005. â€œSonography Clinical Education.â€ Journal Article. Journal of Diagnostic Medical Sonography 21 (3): 273â€“75. https://doi.org/10.1177/8756479305277571.

Creativity in Practice

Sonography is far from a rote or a procedural profession. Every patient presents a new puzzle, and sonographers rely on their creativity for the best results. Ultrasound machines donâ€™t know where to find the best images; itâ€™s up to the sonographerâ€™s skill and intuition to locate the ideal window, angle, or imaging plane. This makes every exam a creative act as much as a technical one.

The literature is full of evidence that engaging in creative activities enhances happiness and well-being (Forgeard and Eichner 2014), and sonography offers a constant opportunity to apply that creativity in real-world settings. Itâ€™s not just the technology of ultrasound that tells the story; itâ€™s the sonographerâ€™s ability to shape a diagnostic story through creative exploration.

Forgeard, Marie J. C., and Katherine V. Eichner. 2014. â€œCreativity as a Target and Tool for Positive Interventions.â€ Book Section. In The Wiley Blackwell Handbook of Positive Psychological Interventions., 137â€“54. Hoboken, NJ, US: Wiley Blackwell. https://doi.org/10.1002/9781118315927.ch7.

The Human Touch in a Technological World

While AI is reaching the stage where it can support image optimisation and analysis, it cannot replace the nuanced expertise required to operate ultrasound technology effectively. The skill of the sonographer lies in the technical manipulation of the transducer, adjusting dynamically for patient anatomy and in their ability to interpret real-time images and make rapid decisions based on clinical context. These capabilities, combined with a sonographerâ€™s ability to communicate with and reassure patients, cannot be easily automated (at least not yet!)

For example, in obstetric imaging, the experience is highly personal. Expectant families rely on the sonographerâ€™s expertise to ensure the best care, trusting that their diagnostic decisions are informed by years of training, hands-on practice, and clinical judgment. While AI tools may assist in tasks like identifying anomalies or labeling anatomical features, the human connection and judgment required to achieve diagnostic accuracy remain critical. Sonography, unlike many other imaging fields, relies on the synergy between human touch and technology.

item.title: Success in sonography - 10 Tips for students
item.description:
Most years, I will discuss concerns regarding a student with a department or supervisor. At times these are work-related and a larger puzzle involving interpersonal issues. At other times it relates directly to the profession and the fundamental roles and responsibilities. The student appears motivated and fits into the team well; however, they are just not clicking with the science and â€œartâ€ that good sonographic practice requires. The student appears to be making the same mistakes, even after various interventions. Often, I believe this requires a responsibility from the student to better reflect on the job and let go of some past experiences in other professions. Ultrasound is different even when compared to other complementary imaging modalities. Sometimes adapting to this new environment can be a challenge.

So, what advice would I give to students commencing this journey? Both academically and practically. Here are ten tips for student sonographers, in no particular order and by no means exclusive. Others may have further additions.

1. Leave the ego at the door.

You are learning something new; you will stumble and sometimes stuff things up and fail. Mistakes will be made, which may directly impact patient care. This is just part of the process. Sonography is hard and involves a manifold set of skills that need to come together in synergy for success. The combination of psychomotor, cognitive clinical reasoning and communication skills is unique to the profession, requiring significant training. It isnâ€™t easy to return to being a little fish as an adult. Success, however, will only come if you are prepared to give in and embrace the learning process. Just because you have excelled in another discipline does not mean you will be ahead of the curve. At times you need to focus hard and challenge yourself to force the mental adaptations to move to the next level. This is uncomfortable and will expose vulnerabilities. It will be painful and dint the ego, but a necessity.

2. Seek excellence, not mastery.

Mastery is a myth, and even the greats will say there are always aspects of their profession, sport, or art they can improve. Develop a willingness to push the boundaries continuously and strive for improvement. Research in the field of skills development identifies a risk of plateauing after a certain level, as individuals become â€œcomfortableâ€ (Ericsson 2008). Embrace professional growth now and throughout your careers. Observe those colleagues you admire in the profession. Undoubtedly, you will find good practice routines, a deep enjoyment in what they do, and a general curiosity in medicine and healthcare. Talent or magic is not part of the equation.

Ericsson, K. A. 2008. â€œDeliberate Practice and Acquisition of Expert Performance: A General Overview.â€ Journal Article. Acad Emerg Med 15 (11): 988â€“94. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1553-2712.2008.00227.x.

3. Become a technology expert.

Good sonographers should strive to be experts in the technology they use. Image optimisation is at the heart of what we do, and a good exam is a synergy between what both hands are doing. One is scanning the patient, the other constantly striving to improve image quality. It is not like a stethoscope, and such analogies should be left to other groups with disparate needs or avoided entirely. Sonographers are coupled to the technology in which success is predicated on a fundamental understanding of correct optimisation strategies. Get to the heart of how the technology works and understand fully what all those wonderful buttons on the machine actually do. Search the settings on your device, setup up your own pre-sets and make the machine sing. You are trying to tell a story for each exam, and the best storytellers utilised good cinematography. A picture tells a thousand words. Suppose you donâ€™t know what a particular setting does or how it should be optimised. Ask! A good source is your friendly applications specialist. They have access to excellent resources and white papers that provide analysis on many elements of the technology.

4. Develop a flexible systematic scanning approach (with a dash of healthy scepticism)

Ultrasound imaging is not simply a procedure requiring a series of pre-determined tasks to be completed in sequence. Imaging protocols only provide a framework. Too often, a student can miss the forest for trees. Listen to what your patient says, ask them, â€œwhy they came into the department today?â€. Does their answer line up with the imaging request? Is there a need to extend the examination or focus more on one aspect? Sonographers need to adapt and be flexible to best answer the clinical question, using alternative image modes, transducers, or variations to the usual patient positioning maneuvers. Even advanced communication skills are the difference between the success or failure of the exam. In a recent article on the impacts of AI, it became clear to my colleagues and me that many elements of what a sonographer does will be difficult for machines to replicate (Edwards et al. 2022). Many are unique to human cognitive understanding and common-sense reasoning. Be systematic in the approach to each organ or region and be critical in the observations you make. Ask yourself if what you are seeing is a true reflection of reality. Ultrasound images are tricky to interpret at times, and a healthy dash of scepticism may alert you to an artifact rather than a significant pathology. Re-read point 3 above.

Edwards, C., C. Chamunyonga, B. Searle, and T. Reddan. 2022. â€œThe Application of Artificial Intelligence in the Sonography Profession: Professional and Educational Considerations.â€ Journal Article. Ultrasound 30 (4): 273â€“82. https://doi.org/10.1177/1742271x211072473.

5. Embrace your peers

Postgraduate ultrasound education should not be viewed as a top-down approach. Learning will not flow exclusively from your supervisors or lecturers at university. Some of the best advice will come from other students or recent graduates. These people often provide a more nuanced or relatable interpretation of the learning process. A sonographer with 30 years of experience is a wealth of knowledge, but at times, that lightbulb moment will come from a fellow student that explains something at your level. The importance of peer learning is increasingly being embedded into postgraduate university programs and has benefits beyond the traditional lecturerâ€“student relationship. Employing students as partners promotes metacognition and a sense of interconnectedness. Form a study group and actively engage other students in your program. Also, be confident that your ideas and interpretations matter; a good supervisor/teacher enjoys both teaching and learning from their students.

6. Seek feedback and be proactive

Take responsibility for your learning. Read your reports and follow up cases that interest you. Regularly engage your colleagues, and if there is an element you would like assistance with, ask for it! Ultrasound departments are hectic, complex environments and students need to use their initiative to enhance their training. Ultrasound training is a privilege and a fantastic opportunity few people get. Donâ€™t remain a passive observer; help out where you can when times are busy, and use your time wisely during quiet periods. Seek feedback from all members of the health care team. Learn from radiologists, cardiologists and other imaging specialists, talk to referrers and gain insights from a wide network.

7. Reflect on the journey in the early stage.

Sonography training is difficult and stressful; this is the truth. Success will require you to manage these in the short term to realise your long-term goals. However, there must be an element of enjoyment in what you do. Struggling in a profession that you learn is the wrong fit has no benefit. The investment in a single student for a department is massive. It wonâ€™t take long to understand what is required and what the future holds. If you realise the career is not for you, step away and pursue something better suited. There is no shame in this, and it demonstrates a level of insight and maturity.

8. Be a scholar

As a university student, read the academic literature and think critically about what you have read. Read full-text articles and donâ€™t simply rely on headlines distilling the virtues of ultrasound. Ultrasound technology does not need to be marketed. It needs to be understood. It is not without its flaws and has many. Understand the limitations and advantages, when it should be employed to improve patient care and when to be avoided. Engage with your professional bodies such as ASA and ASUM. But also challenge them to promote factually correct information backed by peer-reviewed research. If an organisation shares information, check who wrote it and search out and read the research paper. A good paper will discuss any limitations missed in the headline. For example, â€œthe participants in the study were trained athletes and do not represent the broader populationâ€. If a link does not contain direct access to the entire research paper, ask for it or search directly and share it. Suppose the journal paper is behind a pay-wall. In that case, university research repositories, such as QUT ePrints, or national databases such as PubMed.gov often have agreements with the publisher to provide full-text approved versions of papers.

9. Itâ€™s a marathon, not a sprint.

Skills development in ultrasound takes many hours of practice. Be patient. There will be periods where nothing seems to stick, and at others, we hit a period of solid progress, and everything is clicking into gear. Volume and â€œtime in the saddleâ€ are essential components. Consistent regular practice will always trump blocks of training in the long term. Avoid long periods away and line up your periods of academic work with clinical experience. The aim is to embed a deep understanding of the profession. Competency is not an independent list of skills and knowledge; it combines these.

10. Be kind to yourself.

The job is taxing both physically and mentally. The adage of â€œwork hard, play hardâ€ is dead. Productivity in any profession relies on adequate relaxation and plenty of sleep. World-class athletes donâ€™t focus solely on intense training; they also plan sufficient rest and recovery. A combination of both is required for long term growth and improvement. Even God rested on the seventh day. Exercise and a good diet also play a part, and both have broad health benefits.
